'''Typhoon Halong''' was a strong [[tropical cyclone]] that affected the [[Volcano Islands|Volcano]], [[Ogasawara Islands|Ogasawara]], and [[Izu Islands|Izu]] islands before moving north and significantly affecting the western region of [[Alaska]] as an [[extratropical cyclone]] in early October 2025. The twenty-second named storm and the eleventh typhoon of [[2025 Pacific typhoon season|the annual typhoon season]], Halong formed from a broad area of convection south of [[Iwo Jima]] on October 4. Located in a favorable environment, the storm strengthened to a severe tropical storm on October 5 and a typhoon on October 6 as an [[Eye (cyclone)|eye]] began to develop. That same day, Halong rapidly intensified into a very strong typhoon (Category 9 on the [[Saffir–Simpson scale]]), developing a defined, clear eye. Moving northwestward, it gradually weakened due to increasing wind shear and transitioned into an extratropical cyclone on October 10.

Located in a favorable environment, the storm strengthened to a severe tropical storm on October 5 and a typhoon on October 6 as an [[Eye (cyclone)|eye]] began to develop. That same day, Halong rapidly intensified into a very strong typhoon (Category 4 on the [[Saffir–Simpson scale]]), developing a defined, clear eye. Moving northwestward, it gradually weakened due to increasing wind shear and transitioned into an extratropical cyclone on October 10.

== Meteorological history ==
{{storm path|Halong 2025 path.png|colors=new}}On October 3, a broad area of convection developed about {{convert|264|nmi|km}} southeast of [[Iwo Jima]], Japan, with flaring convection along its eastern periphery but no discernible low-level circulation center (LLCC). At that time, the system was situated in a marginally favorable environment, characterized by low to moderate wind shear of {{convert|15-20|kn|kph}}, warm sea surface temperatures of {{cvt|28-29|C|F}}, and moderate outflow aloft.<ref>{{Cite JTWC |date=3 October 2025 |type=abpw |designation=94W|time=15Z|url=https://www.metoc.navy.mil/jtwc/products/abpwweb.txt|access-date=4 October 2025}}</ref> The [[Japan Meteorological Agency]] (JMA){{efn-lg|The JMA is the [[Regional Specialized Meteorological Centre]] (RSMC) for the Western North Pacific.}} began monitoring the system the following day, classifying it as a tropical depression and locating it at 24.8°N 143.9°E.<ref>{{cite web |title=Warning and Summary 040000|url=https://tgftp.nws.noaa.gov/data/raw/ww/wwjp27.rjtd..txt|publisher=Japan Meteorological Agency |access-date=4 October 2025 |date=4 October 2025}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|archive-url=https://archive.today/DHA20#https://megalodon.jp/2025-1005-0410-19/https://www.jma.go.jp:443/bosai/weather_map/%23lang=en--https://archive.today/6iFdI--https://megalodon.jp/2025-1005-0412-04/https://www.data.jma.go.jp:443/yoho/data/wxchart/quick/ASAS_COLOR.pdf }}</ref> Its LLCC later became obscured, caused by persistent convection located directly over the center.<ref>{{Cite JTWC |date=4 October 2025 |type=abpw Formation Alert]] (TCFA) at 06:00 UTC, citing a high chance of development.<ref>{{Cite report |date=4 October 2025 |url=https://www.metoc.navy.mil/jtwc/products/wp9425web.txt |title=Tropical Cyclone |access-date=4 October 2025 |date=4 October 2025}}</ref> The depression intensified into a tropical storm early on October 5 and was named ''Halong'' by the JMA.<ref>{{cite web |title=Warning and Summary 041800|url=https://tgftp.nws.noaa.gov/data/raw/ww/wwjp27.rjtd..txt|publisher=Japan Meteorological Agency |access-date=5 October 2025 |date=5 October 2025}}</ref> As at 18:00 UTC it was located near 24.9°N 142.5°E.<ref name="JTWC1" /> The storm later intensified into a severe tropical storm by the JMA, whilst JTWC further upgraded it into a minimal typhoon on the following day as it slowly == Impact ==

=== Japan ===
=== Japan ===
Halong generated strong waves that left one person dead in Japan.<ref>{{cite web |title=Tokyo's Izu islands see record rainfall as strong typhoon nears |url= https://english.kyodonews.net/articles/-/62474 |publisher=Kyodo News |access-date=October 9, 2025 |date=October 9, 2025}}</ref> On the island of [[Hachijojima]], wind speeds were measured at {{convert|107|kn|mph}} and record rainfall amounts of {{convert|349|mm|in}} were observed.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2025/10/09/japan/typhoon-halong-october/|title=Typhoon Halong brings strong winds and heavy rain to southern Izu islands|author1=Jessica Speed|publisher=The Japan Times|date=October 9, 2025|access-date=October 13, 2025}}</ref> Over 2,700 customers lost water on the island and another 2,200 customers lost power. '''Typhoon Halong''' was a [[tropical cyclone]] that affected the [[Volcano Islands|Volcano]], [[Ogasawara Islands|Ogasawara]], and [[Izu Islands|Izu]] islands before moving north and significantly affecting [[Alaska]] as an [[extratropical cyclone]] in early October 2025. The twenty-second named storm and the eleventh typhoon of [[2025 Pacific typhoon season|the annual typhoon season]], Halong formed from a broad area of convection south of [[Iwo Jima]] on October 4. Located in a favorable environment, the storm strengthened to a severe tropical storm on October 5 and a typhoon on October 6 as an [[Eye (cyclone)|eye]] began to develop. That same day, Halong rapidly intensified into a very strong typhoon (Category 4 on the [[Saffir–Simpson scale]]), developing a defined, clear eye. Moving northwestward, it gradually weakened due to increasing wind shear and transitioned into an extratropical cyclone on October 10.
'''Typhoon Halong''' was a strong [[tropical cyclone]] that affected the [[Volcano Islands|Volcano]], [[Ogasawara Islands|Ogasawara]], and [[Izu Islands|Izu]] islands before moving north and significantly affecting [[Alaska]] as an [[extratropical cyclone]] in early October 2025. The twenty-second named storm and the eleventh typhoon of [[2025 Pacific typhoon season|the annual typhoon season]], Halong formed from a broad area of convection south of [[Iwo Jima]] on October 4. Located in a favorable environment, the storm strengthened to a severe tropical storm on October 5 and a typhoon on October 6 as an [[Eye (cyclone)|eye]] began to develop. That same day, Halong rapidly intensified into a very strong typhoon (Category 4 on the [[Saffir–Simpson scale]]), developing a defined, clear eye. Moving northwestward, it gradually weakened due to increasing wind shear and transitioned into an extratropical cyclone on October 10.

Several roads were left impassible on these islands due to flooding and downed trees.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2025/10/13/japan/typhoon-halong-damage-hachijojjima/|title=Water outages persist on Tokyo’s Hachijojima as second typhoon approaches|author1=Jessica Speed|publisher=The Japan Times|date=October 13, 2025|access-date=October 13, 2025}}</ref>
Halong generated strong waves that left one person dead in Japan.<ref>{{cite web |title=Tokyo's Izu islands see record rainfall as strong typhoon nears |url= https://english.kyodonews.net/articles/-/62474 |publisher=Kyodo News |access-date=October 9, 2025 |date=October 9, 2025}}</ref> On the island of [[Hachijojima]], wind speeds were measured at {{convert|107|kn|mph}} and record rainfall amounts of {{convert|349|mm|in}} were observed.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2025/10/09/japan/typhoon-halong-october/|title=Typhoon Halong brings strong winds and heavy rain to southern Izu islands|author1=Jessica Speed|publisher=The Japan Times|date=October 9, 2025|access-date=October 13, 2025}}</ref> Over 2,700 customers lost water on the island and another 2,200 customers lost power. === Alaska ===
⚫
In Western Alaska, flood and high wind watches were issued ahead of the storm's expected intensification as an extratropical storm in the North Pacific and Bering Sea, where winds up to [[Beaufort scale#Modern mscale|hurricane force]] were expected.<ref>{{cite news|title=Incoming coastal storm looms as Northwest Alaska evacuees return home amid receding floodwaters|url=https://www.adn.com/alaska-news/rural-alaska/2025/10/09/incoming-coastal-storm-looms-as-northwest-alaska-evacuees-return-home-amid-receding-floodwaters/|last=Aadland|first=Chris|publisher=Anchorage Daily News|date=October 9, 2025|accessdate=October 9, 2025}}</ref> These were later upgraded to warnings, with comparisons made to [[Typhoon Merbok (2022)|Ex-Typhoon Merbok]] in 2022, which caused severe flooding in some coastal communities in September 2022. The remnants of Halong brought significant impacts to Alaska, with the worst of the impact in the [[Yukon-Kuskokwim Delta]]. Wind speeds of {{convert|107|mph|kph}} were measured in the [[Kusilvak Mountains]].<ref name = "Fairbanks1">{{Cite news|url=https://www.newsminer.com/alerts/remnants-of-typhoon-halong-bring-widespread-damage-to-western-alaska/article_d779e9fc-fa08-4392-b2d3-b9a84a9dcb8d.html|title=Remnants of Typhoon Halong bring widespread damage to Western Alaska|work=Western Alaska Public Radio|date=October 12, 2025|access-date=October 13, 2025}}</ref> The storm caused record flooding in [[Kipnuk]] and [[Kwigillingok]] where several people went missing after numerous houses were floated off their foundations. The Coast Guard rescued approximately 20 persons from their homes after the buildings had floated out to sea.<ref name="CBS, Race on to find shelter for hundreds, Oct 15, 2025">{{cite web |
In Western Alaska, flood and high wind watches were issued ahead of the storm's expected intensification as an extratropical storm in the North Pacific and Bering Sea, where winds up to [[Beaufort scale#Modern mscale|hurricane force]] were expected.<ref>{{cite news|title=Incoming coastal storm looms as Northwest Alaska evacuees return home amid receding floodwaters|url=https://www.adn.com/alaska-news/rural-alaska/2025/10/09/incoming-coastal-storm-looms-as-northwest-alaska-evacuees-return-home-amid-receding-floodwaters/|last=Aadland|first=Chris|publisher=Anchorage Daily News|date=October 9, 2025|accessdate=October 9, 2025}}</ref> These were later upgraded to warnings, with comparisons made to [[Typhoon Merbok (2022)|Ex-Typhoon Merbok]] in 2022, which caused severe flooding in some coastal communities in September 2022.

⚫
The remnants of Halong brought significant impacts to Alaska, with the worst of the impact in the [[Yukon-Kuskokwim Delta]]. Wind speeds of {{convert|107|mph|kph}} were measured in the [[Kusilvak Mountains]].<ref name = "Fairbanks1">{{Cite news|url=https://www.newsminer.com/alerts/remnants-of-typhoon-halong-bring-widespread-damage-to-western-alaska/article_d779e9fc-fa08-4392-b2d3-b9a84a9dcb8d.html|title=Remnants of Typhoon Halong bring widespread damage to Western Alaska|work=Western Alaska Public Radio|date=October 12, 2025|access-date=October 13, 2025}}</ref> The storm caused record flooding in [[Kipnuk]] and [[Kwigillingok]] where several people went missing after numerous houses were floated off their foundations. The Coast Guard rescued approximately 20 persons from their homes after the buildings had floated out to sea.<ref name="CBS, Race on to find shelter for hundreds, Oct 15, 2025">{{cite web |
title=Race on to find shelter for hundreds from remote Alaskan villages slammed by typhoon's remnants |
title=Race on to find shelter for hundreds from remote Alaskan villages slammed by typhoon's remnants |

website=CBS News |

date=October 15, 2025 |
url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/shelter-sought-hundreds-remote-alaska-villages-slammed-typhoon-halong-remnants/}}</ref> A roof detached from a home and a school boardwalk was damaged in [[Kongiganak]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.newsweek.com/alaska-storm-leaves-20-missing-as-homes-float-away-in-delta-villages-10867494|title=Alaska Storm Leaves 20 Missing as Homes Float Away in Delta Villages|author1=Adeola Adeosun|publisher=Newsweek|date=October 12, 2025|access-date=October 13, 2025}}</ref> Water levels in Kipnuk reached record heights of {{convert|6.6|ft|m}} above [[Chart datum|mean higher high water]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://kyuk.org/public-safety/2025-10-13/officials-say-storm-completely-devastated-western-alaska-communities|title=Officials say storm 'completely devastated' Western Alaska communities|author1=Eric Stone|author2=Liz Ruskin|publisher=KYUK|date=October 13, 2025|access-date=October 14, 2025}}</ref> Boardwalks and roads were submerged across the Yukon-Kuskokwim region, while debris blocked the runway at [[Bethel Airport]] and a barge in [[Bethel, Alaska|Bethel]] broke from its mooring and struck a bridge.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.cbsnews.com/amp/news/alaska-flooding-typhoon-halong/|title=Alaska hit by severe flooding that carries away homes|work=Associated Press|publisher=CBS News|date=October 12, 2025|access-date=October 13, 2025}}</ref><ref name = "Fairbanks1"/> Elsewhere in Western Alaska, strong winds occurred, resulting in roof and siding damage, airborne debris, and extensive tree damage. '''Typhoon Halong''' was a [[tropical cyclone]] that affected the [[Volcano Islands|Volcano]], [[Ogasawara Islands|Ogasawara]], and [[Izu Islands|Izu]] islands before moving north and significantly affecting [[Alaska]] as an [[extratropical cyclone]]. The twenty-second named storm and the eleventh typhoon of [[2025 Pacific typhoon season|the annual typhoon season]], Halong formed from a broad area of convection south of [[Iwo Jima]] on October 4. Located in a favorable environment, the storm strengthened to a severe tropical storm on October 5 and a typhoon on October 6 as an [[Eye (cyclone)|eye]] began to develop. That same day, Halong rapidly intensified into a very strong typhoon (Category 4 on the [[Saffir–Simpson scale]]), developing a defined, clear eye. Moving northwestward, it gradually weakened due to increasing wind shear and transitioned into an extratropical cyclone on October 10.
'''Typhoon Halong''' was a [[tropical cyclone]] that affected the [[Volcano Islands|Volcano]], [[Ogasawara Islands|Ogasawara]], and [[Izu Islands|Izu]] islands before moving north and significantly affecting [[Alaska]] as an [[extratropical cyclone]] in early October 2025. The twenty-second named storm and the eleventh typhoon of [[2025 Pacific typhoon season|the annual typhoon season]], Halong formed from a broad area of convection south of [[Iwo Jima]] on October 4. Located in a favorable environment, the storm strengthened to a severe tropical storm on October 5 and a typhoon on October 6 as an [[Eye (cyclone)|eye]] began to develop. That same day, Halong rapidly intensified into a very strong typhoon (Category 4 on the [[Saffir–Simpson scale]]), developing a defined, clear eye. Moving northwestward, it gradually weakened due to increasing wind shear and transitioned into an extratropical cyclone on October 10.

In addition to the fatalities, over 51 people required rescue after the storm,<ref>{{cite news |title=1 person dead, 2 missing and 51 rescued after massive storm hits Western Alaska |url=https://alaskapublic.org/news/2025-10-13/51-people-rescued-and-at-least-3-still-missing-after-massive-storm-hits-western-alaska |access-date=October 14, 2025 |publisher=Alaska Public Media |date=October 13, 2025}}</ref> with over a thousand people displaced. A thousand emergency meals were also distributed along the coast.<ref>{{cite news |title=One dead, dozens rescued and roughly 1,000 displaced in western Alaska communities hit by ex-typhoon |url=https://alaskabeacon.com/2025/10/13/one-dead-dozens-rescued-and-roughly-1000-displaced-in-western-alaska-communities-hit-by-ex-typhoon/ |access-date=October 14, 2025 |publisher=Alaska Beacon |date=October 13, 2025}}</ref>

'''Typhoon Halong''' was a [[tropical cyclone]] that affected [[Volcano Islands|Volcano]], [[Ogasawara Islands|Ogasawara]], and [[Izu Islands]]. Later, after becoming extratropical, it also affected [[Alaska]]. The twenty-second named storm of [[2025 Pacific typhoon season|the annual typhoon season]], Halong became a tropical depression on October 4, passed [[Iwo Jima]], and then eventually headed northwards.


== Meteorological history ==
== Meteorological history ==
{{storm path|Halong 2025 path.png|colors=new}}On October 3, a broad area of convection developed about {{convert|264|nmi|km}} southeast of [[Iwo Jima]], Japan, with flaring convection along its eastern periphery but no discernible low-level circulation center (LLCC). At that time, the system was situated in a marginally favorable environment, characterized by low to moderate wind shear of {{convert|15-20|kn|kph}}, warm sea surface temperatures of {{cvt|28-29|C|F}}, and moderate outflow aloft.<ref>{{Cite JTWC |date=3 October 2025 |type=abpw |designation=94W|time=15Z|url=https://www.metoc.navy.mil/jtwc/products/abpwweb.txt|access-date=4 October 2025}}</ref> The [[Japan Meteorological Agency]] (JMA){{efn-lg|The JMA is the [[Regional Specialized Meteorological Centre]] (RSMC) for the Western North Pacific.}} began monitoring the system the following day, classifying it as a tropical depression and locating it at 24.8°N 143.9°E.<ref>{{cite web |title=Warning and Summary 040000|url=https://tgftp.nws.noaa.gov/data/raw/ww/wwjp27.rjtd..txt|publisher=Japan Meteorological Agency |access-date=4 October 2025 |date=4 October 2025}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|archive-url=https://archive.today/DHA20#https://megalodon.jp/2025-1005-0410-19/https://www.jma.go.jp:443/bosai/weather_map/%23lang=en--https://archive.today/6iFdI--https://megalodon.jp/2025-1005-0412-04/https://www.data.jma.go.jp:443/yoho/data/wxchart/quick/ASAS_COLOR.pdf |title=気象庁｜天気図 |website=Japan Meteorological Agency |url=https://www.data.jma.go.jp/yoho/data/wxchart/quick/ASAS_COLOR.pdf |archive-date=4 October 2025 |access-date=4 October 2025 |date=4 October 2025 }}</ref> Its LLCC later became obscured, caused by persistent convection located directly over the center.<ref>{{Cite JTWC |date=4 October 2025 |type=abpw |designation=94W|time=03Z|url=https://www.metoc.navy.mil/jtwc/products/abpwweb.txt|access-date=4 October 2025}}</ref> The [[Joint Typhoon Warning Center]] (JTWC) later issued a [[Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert]] (TCFA) at 06:00 UTC, citing a high chance of development.<ref>{{Cite report |date=4 October 2025 |url=https://www.metoc.navy.mil/jtwc/products/wp9425web.txt |title=Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert (Invest 94W) |publisher=Joint Typhoon Warning Center |access-date=4 October 2025}}</ref> The JTWC subsequently followed suit nine hours later at 15:00 UTC and designated the depression as ''28W''.<ref name="JTWC1">{{cite web |title=Tropical Depression 28W (Twenty-eight) Warning No. 1|url= https://www.metoc.navy.mil/jtwc/products/wp2825web.txt |publisher=Joint Typhoon Warning Center |access-date=4 October 2025 |date=4 October 2025}}</ref> The depression intensified into a tropical storm early on October 5 and was named ''Halong'' by the JMA.<ref>{{cite web |title=Warning and Summary 041800|url=https://tgftp.nws.noaa.gov/data/raw/ww/wwjp27.rjtd..txt|publisher=Japan Meteorological Agency |access-date=5 October 2025 |date=5 October 2025}}</ref> As at 18:00 UTC it was located near 24.9°N 142.5°E.<ref name="JTWC1" /> The storm later intensified into a severe tropical storm by the JMA, whilst JTWC further upgraded it into a minimal typhoon on the following day as it slowly tracks northwestwards, with a developing eye and defined cirrus filaments extending poleward.<ref>{{cite web |date=October 6, 2025 |title=Prognostic Reasoning for Typhoon 28W (Halomg) Warning No. 8 |url=https://www.metoc.navy.mil/jtwc/products/wp2825prog.txt |access-date=October 6, 2025 |publisher=Joint Typhoon Warning Center}}</ref>

In Western Alaska, flood and high wind watches were issued ahead of the storm's expected intensification as an extratropical storm in the North Pacific and Bering Sea, where winds up to [[Beaufort scale#Modern scale|hurricane force]] were expected.<ref>{{cite news|title=Incoming coastal storm looms as Northwest Alaska evacuees return home amid receding floodwaters|url=https://www.adn.com/alaska-news/rural-alaska/2025/10/09/incoming-coastal-storm-looms-as-northwest-alaska-evacuees-return-home-amid-receding-floodwaters/|last=Aadland|first=Chris|publisher=Anchorage Daily News|date=October 9, 2025|accessdate=October 9, 2025}}</ref>

== Preparations ==
{{clear}}
{{clear}}


== Impact ==
== Impact ==
Halong generated strong waves that left one person dead in Japan.<ref>{{cite web |title=Tokyo's Izu islands see record rainfall as strong typhoon nears |url= https://english.kyodonews.net/articles/-/62474 |publisher=Kyodo News |access-date=October 9, 2025 |date=October 9, 2025}}</ref> In Western Alaska, flood and high wind watches were issued ahead of the storm's expected intensification as an extratropical storm in the North Pacific and Bering Sea, where winds up to [[Beaufort scale#Modern scale|hurricane force]] were expected.<ref>{{cite news|title=Incoming coastal storm looms as Northwest Alaska evacuees return home amid receding floodwaters|url=https://www.adn.com/alaska-news/rural-alaska/2025/10/09/incoming-coastal-storm-looms-as-northwest-alaska-evacuees-return-home-amid-receding-floodwaters/|last=Aadland|first=Chris|publisher=Anchorage Daily News|date=October 9, 2025|accessdate=October 9, 2025}}</ref> The remnants of Typhoon Halong brought significant impacts to Alaska, with the worst of the impact stretching from [[Wales, Alaska|Wales]] to [[Utqiaġvik]].<ref name = "HalongAK1"/> Wind speeds of {{convert|107|mph|kph}} were measured in [[Kusilvak Census Area, Alaska|Kusilvak]].<ref name = "Fairbanks1">{{Cite news|url=https://www.newsminer.com/alerts/remnants-of-typhoon-halong-bring-widespread-damage-to-western-alaska/article_d779e9fc-fa08-4392-b2d3-b9a84a9dcb8d.html|title=Remnants of Typhoon Halong bring widespread damage to Western Alaska|work=Western Alaska Public Radio|date=October 12, 2025|access-date=October 13, 2025}}</ref> The storm caused record flooding in [[Kwigillingok]] where several people went missing after numerous houses were swept off their foundations. Several other homes were pushed off their foundations in [[Kipnuk]]. A roof detached from a home and a school boardwalk was damaged in [[Kongiganak]]. Water levels in Kongiganak reached record heights of {{convert|6.6|ft|m}}.<ref name = "HalongAK1">{{Cite news|url=https://www.newsweek.com/alaska-storm-leaves-20-missing-as-homes-float-away-in-delta-villages-10867494|title=Alaska Storm Leaves 20 Missing as Homes Float Away in Delta Villages|author1=Adeola Adeosun|publisher=Newsweek|date=October 12, 2025|access-date=October 13, 2025}}</ref> Boardwalks and roads were submerged across the [[Yukon-Kuskokwim Delta|Yukon-Kuskokwim]] region, while debris blocked the runway at [[Bethel, Alaska|Bethel]] [[Bethel Airport|Airport]] and a barge in Bethel broke from its mooring and struck a bridge.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.cbsnews.com/amp/news/alaska-flooding-typhoon-halong/|title=Alaska hit by severe flooding that carries away homes|work=Associated Press|publisher=CBS News|date=October 12, 2025|access-date=October 13, 2025}}</ref><ref name = "Fairbanks1"/> As a result of the typhoon, parts of western Alaska were placed under a disaster declaration by Governor [[Mike Dunleavy]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.juneauempire.com/news/governor-declares-disaster-as-storm-floods-west-and-north-alaska-communities/|title=Governor declares disaster as storm floods west and north Alaska communities|author1=Mari Kanagay|newspaper=Juneau Empire|date=October 11, 2025|access-date=October 13, 2025}}</ref>
{{clear}}
{{clear}}
